head.title: The Excess Wing in the Dielectric Loss of Glass-Formers: A Johari-Goldstein Î²-Relaxation?

article.h1: The Excess Wing in the Dielectric Loss of Glass-Formers: A Johari-Goldstein Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta-Relaxation?

span.span: U. Schneider, R. Brand, P. Lunkenheimer, and A. Loidl
Experimentalphysik V, UniversitÃ¤t Augsburg, D-86135 Augsburg, Germany

article.div: submitted to Phys.Â Rev.Â Lett. 05.01.2000; revised 02.03.2000

div.p: Dielectric loss spectra of glass-forming propylene carbonate and glycerol at temperatures above and below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} are presented. By performing aging experiments lasting up to five weeks, equilibrium spectra below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} have been obtained. During aging, the excess wing, showing up as a second power law at high frequencies, develops into a shoulder. The results strongly suggest that the excess wing, observed in a variety of glass formers, is the high-frequency flank of a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation.

In the frequency-dependent dielectric loss, Îµâ¢"â¢(Î½)ğœ€"ğœˆitalic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(
u), of many glass-formers, an excess contribution to the high-frequency power law of the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{m\alpha}-peak, Îµâ¢"âˆ¼Î½-Î²similar-toğœ€"superscriptğœˆğ›½italic-varepsilon " RELOP:similar-to italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varepsilon"\sim
u^{- eta}, shows up about 2-3 decades above the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{m\alpha}-peak frequency Î½psubscriptğœˆğ‘italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{p}. This excess wing can be reasonably well described by a second power law, Îµâ¢"âˆ¼Î½-bsimilar-toğœ€"superscriptğœˆğ‘italic-varepsilon " RELOP:similar-to italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varepsilon"\sim
u^{-b}, with b<Î²ğ‘ğ›½italic-b RELOP:less-than italic-betab< eta [1, 2, 3]. An excess contribution at high frequencies was already noted in the pioneering work of Davidson and Cole [4] and it is a common feature in glass-forming liquids without a well-resolved Î²ğ›½italic-beta{m eta}-relaxation (see below). The physical origin of the excess wing is commonly considered as one of the great mysteries of glass physics. Despite the fact that some theoretical approaches describing the excess wing have been proposed [5], up to now there is no commonly accepted explanation of its microscopic origin. In addition, some phenomenological descriptions have been proposed [3, 6, 7]. Most successful is the so-called Nagel scaling [6], which leads to a collaps of the Îµâ¢"â¢(Î½)ğœ€"ğœˆitalic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(
u) curves (including the excess wing) for different temperatures and various materials onto one master curve.

In various glass-formers additional relaxation processes, usually termed Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes, are clearly seen in the loss spectra, showing up as a shoulder or even a second peak at Î½>Î½pğœˆsubscriptğœˆğ‘italic-nu RELOP:greater-than italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu>\nu_{p} [7, 8]. Such relaxations in supercooled liquids without intramolecular degrees of freedom were systematically investigated already three decades ago by Johari and Goldstein [8] and basically were ascribed to intrinsic relaxation phenomena of the glass-forming process. We recall that these Johari-Goldstein Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations are fundamentally different from Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations due to intramolecular degrees of freedom. Commonly it is assumed that the excess wing and Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations are different phenomena [6, 7] and even the existence of two classes of glass-formers was proposed - â€type Aâ€ with an excess wing and â€type Bâ€ with a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process [7]. Based on experimental observations it seems natural to explain Johari-Goldstein Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes and excess wing phenomena on the same footing. Indeed such a possibility was already considered earlier [1, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and from an experimental point of view, it cannot be excluded that the excess wing is simply the high-frequency flank of a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak, hidden under the dominating Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak.

However, only the presence of a shoulder with a downward curvature can provide an unequivocal proof for an underlying Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak. In materials with a well pronounced Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak, the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation timescales increasingly separate with decreasing temperature. Therefore, within this picture it may be expected that at low temperatures the excess wing transfers into a shoulder, due to less interference with the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak. In marked contrast to this prediction, for various glass-forming liquids far below the glass temperature Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}, Îµâ¢"â¢(Î½)ğœ€"ğœˆitalic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(\nu) follows a well-developed power law, without any indication of a shoulder [1, 7]. However, measurements of glass-forming materials at low temperatures near or below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} suffer from the fact that thermodynamic equilibrium is not reached in measurements using usual cooling rates. In addition, the loss becomes very low yielding increasingly high experimental uncertainties. Clearly, high-precision equilibrium measurements are necessary to investigate the â€trueâ€ behavior of the excess wing at low temperatures.

Therefore we performed high-precision dielectric measurements keeping the sample at a constant temperature, some KKK{\rm K} below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}, for up to five weeks which ensured that thermodynamic equilibrium was indeed reached. The experiments were performed on two prototypical glass-formers known to exhibit well pronounced excess wings, propylene carbonate (PC, Tgâ‰ˆ159â¢Ksubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”159Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:159 KT_{g}\approx 159~{}{\rm K}) and glycerol (Tgâ‰ˆ185â¢Ksubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”185Kitalic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:185 KT_{g}\approx 185~{}{\rm K}). For the measurements, parallel plane capacitors having an empty capacitance up to 100â¢pF100pFNUMBER:100 pF100~{}{\rm pF} were used. Due to the approach of the fictive [14] towards the real temperature during aging, a thermal contraction of the sample may occur. Its magnitude in one dimension can be estimated to Î”â¢l/lâ‰¤3Ã—10-3Î”ğ‘™ğ‘™3superscript103Delta italic-l MULOP:divide italic-l RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta l/l\leq 3\times 10^{-3},Â which has a negligible effect on the results.Â High-precision measurements of the dielectric permittivity in the frequency range 10-4â¢Hzâ‰¤Î½â‰¤106â¢Hzsuperscript104Hzğœˆsuperscript106HzNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Hz RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-nu RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Hz10^{-4}~{}{\rm Hz}\leq\nu\leq 10^{6}~{}{\rm Hz} were performed using a Novocontrol alpha-analyser. It allows for the detection of values of tanâ¡Î´ğ›¿TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-delta\tan\delta as low as 10-4superscript104NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{-4}. At selected temperatures and aging times, additional frequency sweeps at 20â¢Hzâ‰¤Î½â‰¤1â¢MHz20Hzğœˆ1MHzNUMBER:20 Hz RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-nu RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1 MHz20~{}{\rm Hz}\leq\nu\leq 1~{}{\rm MHz} were performed with the autobalance bridges Hewlett-Packard HP4284 and HP4285. To keep the samples at a fixed temperature for up to five weeks, a closed-cycle refrigerator system was used. The

img.figcaption: Figure 1: Frequency-dependent dielectric loss of PC (a) and glycerol (b) for different aging times tğ‘¡italic-tt (not all shown). The lines connect the symbols for tâ‰¤106â¢sğ‘¡superscript106sitalic-t RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end st\leq 10^{6}~{}{\rm s}. The spectra for the maximum aging time of 106.5â¢ssuperscript106.5sNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s} (â–¡â–¡square\square) have been taken in an extended frequency range.

div.p: sample was cooled from a temperature 20â¢K20KNUMBER:20 K20~{}{\rm K} above Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}Â with the maximum possible cooling rate of about 3â¢K/min3KminNUMBER:3 K MULOP:divide min3~{}{\rm K/min}. The final temperature was reached without any temperature undershoot. As zero point of the aging times reported below, we took the time when the desired temperature was reached, about 200â¢s200sNUMBER:200 s200~{}{\rm s} after passing Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}. The temperature was kept stable within 0.02â¢K0.02KNUMBER:0.02 K0.02~{}{\rm K} during the five weeks measurement time.

Figure 1 shows Îµâ¢"â¢(Î½)ğœ€"ğœˆitalic-varepsilon " OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:)\varepsilon"(\nu) of PC and glycerol at temperatures some KKK{\rm K}Â below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} during aging. A strong dependence of the spectra on aging time tğ‘¡italic-tt is observed. The spectra measured after the maximum time of t=106.5â¢sğ‘¡superscript106.5sitalic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end st=10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s} (squares) are identical to those obtained after t=106â¢sğ‘¡superscript106sitalic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end st=10^{6}~{}{\rm s} (stars), clearly demonstrating that equilibrium was reached. In Fig. 2 these equilibrium spectra are shown, together with equilibrium curves taken at higher temperatures, partly published earlier [15]. Obviously, in the frequency window of Fig. 1 mainly the excess wing region is covered; the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak is located at much lower frequencies, leading to a somewhat steeper increase towards low frequencies only. In Fig. 1 for both materials indeed the typical power law, characteristic of an excess wing, is observed for short tğ‘¡italic-tt. However, with increasing tğ‘¡italic-tt the excess wing successively develops into a shoulder! This behaviour strongly suggests that a relaxation is the origin of the excess wing observed at shorter times or

img.figcaption: Figure 2: Frequency-dependent dielectric loss of PC (a) and glycerol (b) for different temperatures. All curves were taken in thermodynamic equilibrium.

div.p: higher temperatures (Fig. 2). Admittedly, for glycerol the curvature in log10â¡Îµâ¢"â¢(log10â¡Î½)subscript10ğœ€"subscript10ğœˆOPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-varepsilon " OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-nu CLOSE:)\log_{10}\varepsilon"(\log_{10}\nu) is quite subtle (Fig. 1b). However, further evidence is provided by Fig. 3 where the derivatives of the lowest curves in Figs. 1 and 2 are shown. A maximum is observed, clearly indicative of a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process [7]. In the region of the shoulder, the values of tanâ¡Î´ğ›¿TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-delta\tan\deltaÂ ranging between 5Ã—10-35superscript103NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-3} and 2Ã—10-22superscript102NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2\times 10^{-2} are well above the resolution limits of the measurement. In addition, for both materials measurements using the autobalance bridges (not shown) agree well with those obtained with the alpha-analyser. Finally, the response of the empty capacitor was measured at the temperatures of Fig. 1. The resulting loss of Îµâ¢"<1.5Ã—10-4ğœ€"1.5superscript104italic-varepsilon " RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varepsilon"<1.5\times 10^{-4} in the region of 10â¢Hzâ‰¤Î½â‰¤100â¢kHz10Hzğœˆ100kHzNUMBER:10 Hz RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-nu RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:100 kHz10~{}{\rm Hz}\leq\nu\leq 100~{}{\rm kHz} excludes a non-intrinsic origin of the observed shoulder.

The results of Fig. 1Â are interpreted as follows: During aging the fictive temperature [14] successively approaches the â€realâ€ temperature leading to a strong shift of the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak towards lower frequencies. The relaxation times of Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes usually exhibit a weaker temperature dependence than those of the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-process. Therefore the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process causing the excess wing can be expected to be less affected by the aging. The different aging depencences of the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process can also easily be deduced from the fact that the spectra at different aging times cannot be scaled onto each other by a horizontal shift in Fig. 1. In addition, aging experiments reported by Johari and

img.figcaption: Figure 3: Derivative of the dielectric loss spectra obtained after 106.5â¢ssuperscript106.5sNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s}. The lines correspond to the fits shown in Fig. 4.

div.p: coworkers [8] revealed a negligible change of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak frequency with aging time [16]. Overall, with increasing aging time, respectively decreasing effective temperature, the time scales of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process become successively separated and finally the presence of a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation is revealed by the appearence of a shoulder.

A close inspection of dielectric measurements at low temperatures,Â reported in literature, reveals some further evidence of a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation being the origin of the excess wing: Already in the spectrum obtained by Leheny and Nagel [17] after aging of glycerol for 2.5Ã—106â¢s2.5superscript106sNUMBER:2.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s2.5\times 10^{6}~{}{\rm s} at 177.6â¢K177.6KNUMBER:177.6 K177.6~{}{\rm K} a vague indication for a shoulder is present. However, possibly due to doubt of its significance, these authors payed no attention to this feature. In addition, in various other published results, near or just below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}Â some indications for a shoulder show up [1, 3, 13, 15, 18], again being ignored in most of these publications. Except for [13] the thermal history was not reported in detail and it can be doubted if thermal equilibrium was reached. In the study of Wagner and Richert [13], in highly quenched Salol a strong secondary peak appeared below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} which vanished after heating to Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}. In addition, in isochronal measurements of various quenched glass-formers [19] non-equilibrium secondary relaxations were detected. From the results in [13, 19] the question arises if the subtle indications for a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation seen around Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} in [1, 3, 13, 15, 18] are pure non-equilibrium effects and if this relaxation may completely vanish in equilibrium. Only the present aging experiments could prove that the excess wing is due to a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation that is an equilibrium phenomenon. In Fig. 1 the amplitude of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak (only seen as excess wing at short times) may be suspected to diminish with aging. Interestingly, in systems with well resolved Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations a similar behavior was observed [8, 9]. Finally it should be mentioned that in [20] evidence of a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation in various systems without a clearly resolvable second relaxation peak (including PC) was found by using a â€difference isochroneâ€ method.

img.figcaption: Figure 4: Dielectric loss spectra obtained after 106.5â¢ssuperscript106.5sNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end s10^{6.5}~{}{\rm s}. TheÂ solid lines are fits with a sum of a CD (dashed line) and a CC function (dash-dotted).

div.p: In addition, in glycerol a high-frequency shoulder was detected by performing high-pressure dielectric experiments [21]. Further evidences for Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations in typical excess-wing glass-formers have also been obtained from other experimental methods, e.g. calorimetry [23] or nuclear magnetic resonance [24]. A strong corroboration of the present results is also provided by our recent results in ethanol, which prove that the well-pronounced excess wing in this glass-former is also due to a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation [22].

What further information on the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation causing the excess wing can be gained from the present data? The Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peaks in PC and glycerol can well be fitted using the empirical Cole-Davidson (CD) function [4, 15]. In materials with well pronounced Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peaks their spectral shape often can be described by the Cole-Cole (CC) function [25]. In Fig. 4 we demonstrate that the equilibrium curves of Fig. 1 can well be fitted using a sum of a CD and a CC function. Similar analyses were performed in [1, 10, 11, 12]. In Fig. 3 the corresponding derivatives are shown â€“ again a reasonable agreement can be stated. In the same way also the present spectra at higher temperatures (Fig. 2) can be described [26]. The resulting characteristics of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations in PC and glycerol can be summarized as follows: i) The relaxation strength increases with Tğ‘‡italic-TT. This is often found for well resolved Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations, e.g. in [7]. ii) The width of the relaxation peaks becomes smaller with Tğ‘‡italic-TT, which is also a common property of well separated Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations [7] iii) Despite some difficulty to obtain precise information on the temperature development of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation time, Ï„Î²subscriptğœğ›½italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{\beta}, the analysis reveals significant deviations from thermally activated behavior [26]. Therefore one may have objections using the term â€Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxationâ€ in this case, as they are commonly assumed to follow an Arrhenius behavior. However, there is no principle reason that Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-processes always should behave thermally activated, especially as their microscopic origin is still unclear. Already Johari [8] suspected that in systems without a well resolved Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process, the relaxation times of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-process are closer together due to an uncommon temperature dependence of Ï„Î²subscriptğœğ›½italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{\beta}. Maybe the only difference between â€type Aâ€ and â€type Bâ€ glass-formers in the classification scheme of [7] is just the temperature evolution of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-dynamics: In the latter materials it is thermally activated, leading to a clear separation of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak at low temperatures. In contrast, in â€type Aâ€ materials Ï„Î²â¢(T)subscriptğœğ›½ğ‘‡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\tau_{\beta}(T) follows more closely Ï„Î±â¢(T)subscriptğœğ›¼ğ‘‡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\tau_{\alpha}(T) (i.e., it deviates from Arrhenius) and only the high-frequency flank of the Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-peak â€“ the excess wing â€“ is visible. The Nagel-scaling [6], which strongly suggests a correlation between the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-process and the excess wing in â€type Aâ€ systems, is not opposed to this framework: It simply implies that in those materials the parameters characterizing both relaxation processes are intimately related.

In this context it is of interest that recently for â€type Bâ€ glass-formers a correlation of Ï„Î²subscriptğœğ›½italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{\beta} and the Kohlrausch-exponent Î²Kâ¢Wâ¢Wsubscriptğ›½ğ¾ğ‘Šğ‘Šitalic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{KWW} (describing the width of the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}-peak), both at Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g}, was found [27]: logÏ„Î²10â¢(Tg)subscriptsubscriptğœğ›½10subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){}_{10}\tau_{\beta}(T_{g}) increases monotonically with Î²Kâ¢Wâ¢Wâ¢(Tg)subscriptğ›½ğ¾ğ‘Šğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{KWW}(T_{g}). It was noted that those glass-formers that show no well-resolved Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation (including PC and glycerol) have relatively large values of Î²Kâ¢Wâ¢Wâ¢(Tg)subscriptğ›½ğ¾ğ‘Šğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{KWW}(T_{g}). As the mentioned correlation implies that the Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha{\rm\alpha}- and Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-timescales approach each other with increasing Î²Kâ¢Wâ¢Wâ¢(Tg)subscriptğ›½ğ¾ğ‘Šğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K italic-W italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{KWW}(T_{g}), the unobservability of a shoulder in those materials is easily rationalized. In [27] an explanation of this behavior within the coupling model (CM) [28] was proposed. Recently it was shown that the Nagel-scaling can be explained within this framework [11] and even the deviation of Ï„Î²â¢(T)subscriptğœğ›½ğ‘‡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)\tau_{\beta}(T) from thermally activated behavior seems to be consistent with the CM.

In summary, by performing high-precision measurements below Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{g} in thermodynamic equilibrium we were able to resolve the presence of Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations in two typical excess wing glass-formers. Our results strongly suggest that the so-far mysterious excess wing, showing up at higher temperatures, is simply the high-frequency flank of the loss-peaks caused by these Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxations. Of course, the mere identification of the excess wing with a Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation provides no explanation, e.g. forÂ the Nagel scaling [6] or the question why glass-formers seem to fall into two classes - those with a well-separated Î²ğ›½italic-beta{\rm\beta}-relaxation and those without [7]. But the knowledge of the true nature of the excess wing certainly is a prerequisite for any microscopic explanation of these phenomena, (e.g. [11, 27]) and hopefully will enhance our understanding of the glass transition in general.
We thank K.L.Â Ngai for stimulating dicussions. This work was supported by the DFG, Grant-No. LO264/8-1 and partly by the BMBF, contract-No. EKM 13N6917.
